After reading all the negative reviews i felt that i had to post a positive one due to all the unfair flak the devs are getting.

I run, gun and have a blast (literally, artillery is a menace) but got 500+ hours and 35 in the last two weeks alone with absolutely no more than 1 problem (i managed to get myself stuck but that was just silly QA in me messing around) overall i would give it a strong 7.5/10 with improvements possible in LODDING in particular with stone walls being invisible over extreme distances (+500m) making it hard to make long range small arms combat work.

Outside of this issue (which is a general issue across FPS titles) lets look at some gameplay stuff
PRO's
- Gunplay is amazing, good animations and solid audio for all of em.
- Directional and distance amibance for audio is above and beyond (watching explosions then getting the audio second delays on distance is such an incredible feel)
- Good mix between arcade and realism usage such as blast ranges, damage dealing and so on.
- Continued polish from the devs and added functionality for weapons and more (bipods working and a lot more usable now!)
- Hit detection works pretty damn well (i really dont get why all the negative comments about this is coming from but considering i generally have 0 problems getting hits nor kills i dont want to say it but...skill issue? or latency problems (i play on +150 ms servrs so idk...)).
- Open for feedback (double edged sword, check cons)

CON's
- Lack of feedback responce in open channels (not really clear what data is used for things like cost adjustments etc)
- The community biting itself and can be outright hostile if you make mistakes.( the devs have 0 control over this, its entirely a competetive sore loser problem on some servers )
- Some parts of the gameplay loop is very static and not very interesting (nodes and arty vs recon and its expected role, but this is also something being worked on )
- Lack of protection in Streamer mode (it doesnt hide the map, please fix this as stream sniping is annoying and trying to manually block the map with an overlay through recording software is absolutely insane)
Realistic, nice to have game that is not bullet sponges because hs is hs and time to kill is nice and realistic. if ppl would play more in team and use mic it would be even better experience.

I won't say that there isn't anything quite like it, because that's just not true, there's tons of games like it; but [i]Hell Let Loose[/i] is a very good example of its genre. It's totally distinct from arena shooters or extraction shooters or whatever else the kids play these days, it has a lot more going on than those do, if not in moment to moment gameplay than in the big picture. It's not so complicated as to be obtuse to those who have never played a game like it though, I was once one of those people but now I pretty much have the basics down in most categories and actually help my team.

It feels satisfying to win a duel not because you got a kill but because you stayed alive. Actually killing people is usually secondary to tasks like placing spawn points for your team or destroying them for the enemy. That's fun, that means you can have a good time just from using your head even if you can't aim for shit. Small arms not your thing? Try artillery where you never see the enemy but you sure can blow them up if you know what you're doing (I don't). Maybe you don't care for combat much at all, just be a truck driver then delivering supplies around the map and helping everyone out. Depending on my mood I'll do any one of these jobs or something else entirely, there's a lot of options.

I paid more for this game than I usually would for a multiplayer game, but it was worth it. They add new stuff pretty frequently and the community is one of the best I've ever played with. Obviously not everyone is nice, especially to newcomers, but as long as you're honest that you suck most people will help you out until you can be the one helping out. Not too many obnoxious cosmetics either, everything is pretty authentic to the setting which is a major boon in 2025 when most games start to look like [i]Fortnite[/i] after a couple years.

No other WWII FPS game has come close to this. It's not for the feint of heart as you will always die from some random stuff but the kill streaks will be epic. It has successfully combined an addictive FPS action shooter with a multiplayer Coop and strategy game. If can't work with others, don't play. But if you can, glory awaits.

Its very similar to rising storm 2 or red orchestra 2, the difference is only in the pace, its a bit slower. The commander and  squad leader classes are a little bit more complex. And this game really needs you to communicate with your team, get that voice chat on. Although not as active as foxhole, its still fun. The Gun feels great and powerful, Its very realistic, and unique.

I have no problem with the walking but I had to wait in a great spot for a minute or two until I see some enemy coming in. And the grind for the better weapons are so long, It's probably one of the longest in any fps games that I've played. Not only that but the xp you get from a match can only get you so far because of the big maps that cause u to meet less enemy. Before I play this game, I heard that the engagement distance in hll especially in afrika is mostly very far, so basically a pixel wide of enemy, and its true. And destroying enemy's outposts or resources or garrisons or even killing enemies itself doesnt rewards you with a lot of xp. So it's better to just hunker down in an objective doing nothing and wait for the enemy instead of being active. I had a game where I became a rifleman, get a lot of kills, destroy garrisons and outpost and still doesnt get enough xp, I'd still get outshined by easy class like machinegunners that just do supressions on the enemy. I didnt even get a new level, It was an hour+ match, And I had the most xp and was the most active in my squad. Its like as if hunting enemy spawn isn't worth it. 
 I'd say that if you came from call of duty or battlefield, its best that you try something like rising storm or red orchestra first before entering this game. I saw a lot of people, enemy or teammate that charge blindly into the battlefield without looking left and right, and they would easily get flanked. In afrika I got 10+ kills in a point while lying down with 2 enemy panzers inches away from me.

This last update has thrown a lot of people, both new and old, into a fire, with issues with crashing, stability, and general server connections. The devs are actively fixing and patching it, and the last year or 2 has been one of the best for both maps and listening to the community, even with the issues update 18 came with. Gameplay-wise, think of Squad but with more arcade feel when it comes to guns and lives. Still a milsim, so you'll be punished if you don't coordinate or die while being overly aggressive. The biggest issue this game has, and will always have, is command chat, commanders, and people without mics. If you're new, don't make a squad till you at least start having a mic. The only time you shouldn't have a mic is when you're really experienced, and even then, you are crippling your team.

TLDR: game is good, and really arcade milsim is easier to get into than Squad. Current review reflects issues within the last update, which devs are actively fixing.

Second, their handling of the recent rollout of their update gone wrong has been nothing short of a fresh breath of air. The response was a bit slow, but soon not only did devs give regular updates, but have taken steps to ensure the same mistakes don't happen again, AND kept communication on discord, reddit, etc constant and up to date.

For a problem that only gravely affected 1/7th the player base (based on reddit polling), I have nothing but praise.

Hell Let Loose continues to be one of the most intense and rewarding FPS experiences out there. Every match feels like a real battle not just because of the sound design and visuals, but because teamwork actually matters. When your squad is communicating, marking targets, and coordinating with command, the game becomes a lot more immersive.

The maps are huge and detailed, the gunplay is satisfying without being arcadey, and the pacing strikes a perfect balance between tactical and chaotic. Even after hundreds of hours, no two matches feel the same.

It’s one of the few shooters where victory truly comes from coordination, not just individual skill. If you enjoy immersive, strategy-heavy FPS games, Hell Let Loose is absolutely worth playing.

Bullets whiz by and you have absolutely no idea where from and you will be picked off by people you cannot see. 

Keep your cool and persist. It is not CoD or BF or any other shooter game you are good at, Dying is part of the game, Infantry die. This game requires tactical thinking! you need to be able to read your map, these maps are gigantic! Study the map predict where the enemy will be and where they have been spotted and plan your movements accordingly! Each class plays a very specific role.

There is a known bug where left leaning around a corner makes you completely invisible to the enemy, so remember that if you're killed and you have absolute no idea how.

Also keep in mind there are people in this game who have put ungodly amount of hours into this AND take it very seriously!, some will kick you for being too low level or not using your mic. Look for servers that say "New players welcome" your life will be much easier (these also tend to be the fullest servers)

Hell Let Loose – A Masterpiece… When It Actually Lets You Play

I absolutely love Hell Let Loose. The graphics, the atmosphere, the sound design, the gameplay — it’s pure cinema. When the game works, it delivers some of the most immersive and intense battles I’ve ever experienced.

But actually getting into a game with friends? That’s a whole different war.

Trying to find a server with enough space and good ping is already a mission. Then you finally join, you play for three minutes… and one friend gets disconnected for no reason. So you try another server, only for someone to get kicked because they’re “not speaking on the mic” despite having barely joined the match.

And this loop repeats. For an hour.

In the end, it feels like we spend more time fighting the server browser than fighting the enemy. It’s frustrating, it’s a waste of our time, and it takes away from what is otherwise an incredible experience.

Hell Let Loose is brilliant — it just needs to stop letting players loose from the server every five minutes.

Its ok. 
BUT.
Like with every shooter game with intrusive foliage ( MUH IMMURSHON-grass), foliage is in bad need of removal or reworking. It is exploitable to infuriating degree, to point where you may be laying down in a ditch full of grass, but for anyone past 100m, you may be plain visible from even slightly elevated position. And you can't even see what kills you. 
Terrain/map feature wise:
Trenches in maps are too narrow, people cannot get past one another in them. 
Most windows are either too low or too high to be of any use, for anything.

you will also for some reason become blind shellshocked drooling vegetable if a single bullet so much as passes you within 1m radius. your eyes will cross so hard you will be able to see close up view of your own nasal bridge. They cross so high that any more and you'll risk being able to see in the fourth and fifth dimension at the same time, with how absolutely fouled up, up your sight is. 
Now imagine how bad it gets when machine gun opens up anywhere near you. 
Which, mechanically, by the way, is idiots invention. It could be understandable if explosions had such effect. But not with bullets. The make believe suppression effect, is just plain bad. 
It is so bad that i almost understand why someone might want to cheat in the game.

Your view point is actually at your neck, rather than where your eyes actually are, so even if you think you are hidden, someone is going to pop your dome and you can't even accurately tell why it happened because you cant tell, if part of you is visible to the enemy. 

And speaking of visibility, there are a lot of people trying to shoot you through solid cover. Whichever magic it is that they use to see you then, who knows. But you will see that often enough to be too much.

EDIT:
Most of the time you end up having to play a squad leader because nobody else will do it, and for that, there is a reason because after you reach level 6 as squad lead, you get exactly nothing worthwhile for the effort. Squad leaders need more loadouts or ability to rank up other specializations with the xp they gain so there might be at least a theoretical reason for why anyone would want to play as one.
